title: Visualizations
text:
LA Airbnb Visualizations
This page shows several key visualizations from our analysis and highlights the enriched variables we created: price per person, amenity flags, annual revenue, stay type, and review score.



Code
### Visualization: Price Distribution 
import plotly.express as px
# Filter price range for visualization
price_cap = 500
df_price_plot = df[df['price_num'].between(0, price_cap)]

fig_price_dist = px.histogram(
    df_price_plot,
    x='price_num',
    nbins=50,
    title='Distribution of Nightly Price (0–$500)',
    labels={'price_num': 'Nightly price (USD)'}
)
fig_price_dist.show()


                            
                                            



Nightly Price Distribution (0–$500) The distribution of nightly prices in Los Angeles is right-skewed, with most listings clustered between $80 and $250 per night. This indicates that while LA does have luxury, high-priced properties, they represent a small portion of the market. The majority of Airbnb listings fall into a moderate and affordable price range.



Code
# if we want to show price per person 
price_pp_cap = 250
df_pp_plot = df[df['price_per_person'].between(0, price_pp_cap)]

fig_price_pp = px.histogram(
    df_pp_plot,
    x='price_per_person',
    nbins=50,
    title='Distribution of Nightly Price per Person',
    labels={'price_per_person': 'Price per person (USD)'}
)
fig_price_pp.show()


                            
                                            



Price Per Person Distribution When adjusting for the number of guests accommodated, price-per-person becomes much more concentrated, typically between $20 and $80 per person. This suggests that many higher-priced listings actually offer good value when shared by multiple guests. The distribution also highlights affordability differences between solo



Code
### Visualization: Room type vs price 
df_room_plot = df[df['price_num'].between(0, price_cap)]

fig_room_price = px.box(
    df_room_plot,
    x='room_type',
    y='price_num',
    title='Price by Room Type (0–$500)',
    labels={'room_type': 'Room type', 'price_num': 'Nightly price (USD)'}
)
fig_room_price.show()


                            
                                            



Box Plot — Price by Room Type Entire homes/apartments consistently have the highest price range, with a noticeably larger spread and more extreme high-end listings. Private rooms tend to be moderately priced with lower variability, while shared rooms remain the most budget-friendly and tightly clustered. This pattern reflects the premium placed on privacy and full-property access.



                            
                                            



Top 15 Most Expensive Neighborhoods (Bar Chart) The most expensive neighborhoods show dramatically higher average prices, reflecting areas with luxury properties or tourist-driven demand. These neighborhoods cluster around premium coastal or central LA zones. The significant price differences indicate how strongly location influences listing value.



Code
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px

# Clean price column if not already done
df['price_num'] = pd.to_numeric(
    df['price'].str.replace(r'[\$,]', '', regex=True),
    errors='coerce'
)

# Filter rows with valid ratings + prices
df_reviews = df[
    df['review_scores_rating'].notna() &
    df['price_num'].notna()
].copy()

# ----- Choose fixed filter values -----
min_rating = 4.0     # minimum acceptable review score
max_price = 500      # maximum price to show
# --------------------------------------

# Apply the filters
filtered = df_reviews[
    (df_reviews['review_scores_rating'] >= min_rating) &
    (df_reviews['price_num'] <= max_price)
]

# Build title
title = f"Price vs Review Score (Rating ≥ {min_rating}, Price ≤ ${max_price})"

# Create scatter plot
fig = px.scatter(
    filtered,
    x="review_scores_rating",
    y="price_num",
    color="room_type",
    opacity=0.6,
    title=title,
    labels={
        "review_scores_rating": "Review Score Rating",
        "price_num": "Nightly Price (USD)",
        "room_type": "Room Type"
    }
)

fig.update_layout(height=500)
fig.show()


                            
                                            


Price vs. Review Score (Static Visualization): This scatter plot explores whether higher guest review scores are associated with higher nightly prices.
Listings are filtered to include only properties with strong ratings (4.0 or above) and prices under $500 per night.
Each point represents an Airbnb listing, colored by room type.
The chart shows that while higher-rated listings span a wide range of prices, extremely low-rated listings tend to cluster at cheaper price points, suggesting that quality and guest satisfaction can influence pricing but are not the only determining factors.

title: Interactive
text:
This page includes our interactive widgets:
Description: A review score vs. price explorer with filters for rating and maximum price
These tools allow users to explore how price varies across neighborhoods and how it relates to guest ratings.
For a demonstration of an interactive widget, see @interact.


Code
import pandas as pd
from pathlib import Path

data_path = Path("C:/Users/adans/OneDrive/Documents/Data Science/Project25/_Final Project - Boston Airbnb/~Final Project - Boston Airbnb/Data/LA_Airbnb_ALL.csv")

df = pd.read_csv(data_path)
# Load LA Airbnb Data
import pandas as pd
from pathlib import Path

data_path = Path("C:/Users/adans/OneDrive/Documents/Data Science/Project25/_Final Project - Boston Airbnb/~Final Project - Boston Airbnb/Data/LA_Airbnb_ALL.csv")

df = pd.read_csv(data_path)


# Missing Values
missing = df.isna().sum().sort_values(ascending=False)


# Top 3 Missing Values
top3_missing = missing.head(3)

# Clean price — robust handling
df["price_num"] = (
    df["price"]
    .astype(str)
    .str.replace(r"[\$,]", "", regex=True)
    .str.replace(",", "", regex=False)
)

df["price_num"] = pd.to_numeric(df["price_num"], errors="coerce")

# Remove missing/zero prices
df = df[df["price_num"].notna() & (df["price_num"] > 0)]




Code
### Interactive Review score
import ipywidgets as widgets
from ipywidgets import interact
import plotly.express as px



df_reviews = df[df['review_scores_rating'].notna()].copy()

@interact(
    min_rating=widgets.IntSlider(value=80, min=0, max=100, step=5, description='Min rating:'),
    max_price=widgets.IntSlider(value=400, min=50, max=1000, step=50, description='Max price:')
)
def review_score_widget(min_rating, max_price):
    data = df_reviews[
        (df_reviews['review_scores_rating'] >= min_rating) &
        (df_reviews['price_num'] <= max_price)
    ]
    
    title = f'Price vs Review Score (rating ≥ {min_rating}, price ≤ ${max_price})'
    
    fig = px.scatter(
        data,
        x='review_scores_rating',
        y='price_num',
        color='room_type',
        title=title,
        labels={
            'review_scores_rating': 'Review score rating',
            'price_num': 'Nightly price (USD)',
            'room_type': 'Room type'
        },
        opacity=0.6
    )
    fig.show()





Review Score vs. Price: This widget lets users study how nightly prices relate to review scores. Listings with higher review scores tend to have a wide range of prices, indicating that guests evaluate factors beyond price alone, such as cleanliness or amenities. Very low-rated listings are relatively rare and tend to have lower prices. Overall, the visualization suggests no strong linear relationship between price and rating.

title: LA Airbnb
text: Project created by Alyssa Dansby and Abby Sullivan

title: LA Airbnb
text:
Project Overview
This site summarizes our analysis of Airbnb listings in Los Angeles.
We document our data sources, cleaning, enrichment (price per person, amenities, annual revenue, stay type), and key results.

title: LA Airbnb
text:
Motivation — Why This Analysis Matters
Airbnb markets vary dramatically across cities, and LA is one of the most competitive markets in the U.S. Hosts, travelers, policymakers, and businesses need insights into:

What determines how much a listing costs
What influences guest demand and satisfaction
How neighborhood location affects revenue
How hosts can optimize pricing and occupancy

Understanding these patterns helps inform business decisions, regulation, and consumer behavior.

title: LA Airbnb
text:
Data and Methods

Data source: LA Airbnb listings scraped from Airbnb dtaset (LA_Airbnb_ALL.csv)
Raw format: CSV file with one row per listing and columns for price, location, reviews, etc.
Cleaning & enrichment:

Converted nightly price from strings to numeric.
Created price per person = price / accommodates.
Parsed amenities into a list, then flagged WiFi, kitchen, free parking, pool, air conditioning.
Used estimated occupancy to compute annual revenue.
Categorized listings by stay type (short / medium / long) using minimum nights.

Tools: Python, pandas, plotly, ipywidgets, Quarto.

For full details see the visualizations and interactive pages.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: Interactive
text:
This page includes our interactive widgets:
Description: A review score vs. price explorer with filters for rating and maximum price
These tools allow users to explore how price varies across neighborhoods and how it relates to guest ratings.
For a demonstration of an interactive widget, see @interact.


Code
import pandas as pd
from pathlib import Path
import plotly.io as pio
pio.renderers.default = "iframe"

data_path = Path("C:/Users/adans/OneDrive/Documents/Data Science/Project25/_Final Project - Boston Airbnb/~Final Project - Boston Airbnb/Data/LA_Airbnb_ALL.csv")

df = pd.read_csv(data_path)
# Load LA Airbnb Data
import pandas as pd
from pathlib import Path

data_path = Path("C:/Users/adans/OneDrive/Documents/Data Science/Project25/_Final Project - Boston Airbnb/~Final Project - Boston Airbnb/Data/LA_Airbnb_ALL.csv")

df = pd.read_csv(data_path)


# Missing Values
missing = df.isna().sum().sort_values(ascending=False)


# Top 3 Missing Values
top3_missing = missing.head(3)

# Clean price — robust handling
df["price_num"] = (
    df["price"]
    .astype(str)
    .str.replace(r"[\$,]", "", regex=True)
    .str.replace(",", "", regex=False)
)

df["price_num"] = pd.to_numeric(df["price_num"], errors="coerce")

# Remove missing/zero prices
df = df[df["price_num"].notna() & (df["price_num"] > 0)]




Code
### Interactive Review Score

import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px
import ipywidgets as widgets
from ipywidgets import interact

### Interactive Review score
df_reviews = df[df['review_scores_rating'].notna()].copy()

@interact(
    min_rating=widgets.IntSlider(value=80, min=0, max=100, step=5, description='Min rating:'),
    max_price=widgets.IntSlider(value=400, min=50, max=1000, step=50, description='Max price:')
)
def review_score_widget(min_rating, max_price):
    data = df_reviews[
        (df_reviews['review_scores_rating'] >= min_rating) &
        (df_reviews['price_num'] <= max_price)
    ]
    
    title = f'Price vs Review Score (rating ≥ {min_rating}, price ≤ ${max_price})'
    
    fig = px.scatter(
        data,
        x='review_scores_rating',
        y='price_num',
        color='room_type',
        title=title,
        labels={
            'review_scores_rating': 'Review score rating',
            'price_num': 'Nightly price (USD)',
            'room_type': 'Room type'
        },
        opacity=0.6
    )
    return fig





Review Score vs. Price: This widget lets users study how nightly prices relate to review scores. Listings with higher review scores tend to have a wide range of prices, indicating that guests evaluate factors beyond price alone, such as cleanliness or amenities. Very low-rated listings are relatively rare and tend to have lower prices. Overall, the visualization suggests no strong linear relationship between price and rating.

title: Visualizations
text:
For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see Figure 1.


Code
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()








Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis
